reasoning: The critique targets a specific sub-argument in the position’s item (5): the inference that a declining *count* of near-frontier experiments despite progress implies near-frontier experiments aren’t a bottleneck. That point is supportive but not load-bearing for the overall thesis (which gives many independent reasons to doubt compute bottlenecks), so centrality is modest. The critique offers a coherent alternative statistic (frontier-equivalent compute/year rather than run count) and a plausible historical counter-model (fewer but larger/more decisive runs), which substantially weakens that particular inference, though it doesn’t address the author’s other reply (that near-frontier runs may not be needed at all). The claims are largely conceptually correct and empirically plausible, clearly stated, tightly focused, and contain little to no filler.
title: Fewer but larger frontier runs could still be the binding bottleneck
